title: Words in Context Mastery
subtitle: Precision of Meaning & Tone
learning_objectives: Interpret precise meaning of words and phrases in context
Differentiate between dictionary definition and contextual meaning
Avoid traps that 'sound right' but distort meaning

content.heading: What's Tested
content.text: The SAT tests your ability to understand words and phrases as they're used in specific contexts, not just their dictionary definitions.
bullet_points: Context-specific meaning takes priority over dictionary definition
Pay attention to connotation: positive, negative, or neutral tone
Look for structural clues around the target word
Avoid traps that sound right but don't fit the context

interactions.text: Ready to master context clues? Click to continue

content.heading: Context vs. Dictionary Definition
content.text: Many words have multiple meanings. The SAT wants you to choose the meaning that best fits the specific passage context.

concept_box.title: Key Example
points: üéØ **The right choice** depends entirely on how the author uses it

examples.passage_excerpt: The scientist's novel approach to the problem yielded unexpected results.
examples.context_clue: 'Approach to the problem' suggests method/technique, not literature

elements.trigger: Click to see why context wins
elements.reveal: Here, 'novel approach' clearly means 'new method' because we're talking about scientific problem-solving, not reading a book!

content.heading: 3-Step Context Analysis

strategy_steps.title: READ THE SENTENCE
strategy_steps.description: Look at the complete sentence containing the word
strategy_steps.example: Cover the target word and read around it

strategy_steps.title: CHECK THE TONE
strategy_steps.description: Is the context positive, negative, or neutral?

strategy_steps.title: SUBSTITUTE & TEST
strategy_steps.description: Replace with each answer choice and see what fits
strategy_steps.example: The choice that maintains tone and logic wins

content.memory_aid: Remember: **R.C.S.** - Read, Check tone, Substitute & test

slides.title: Guided Practice: Let's Apply the Strategy

passage.text: The detective's investigation was thorough, but the suspect's alibi proved to be **solid**. Despite hours of questioning, she could not find any inconsistencies or weaknesses in his account of the evening's events.

guided_questions.question: READ: What is the complete context around 'solid'?
guided_questions.hint: Look at what comes before and after the target word.
guided_questions.answer: The alibi 'proved to be solid' and there were 'no inconsistencies or weaknesses'
guided_questions.explanation: The context is about an alibi that couldn't be broken down or disproven.

guided_questions.question: CHECK TONE: Is this positive or negative for the suspect?
guided_questions.hint: Think about whether having a solid alibi helps or hurts the suspect.
guided_questions.answer: Positive for the suspect - it protects him from accusation
guided_questions.explanation: A solid alibi is good for the suspect because it means his story holds up under scrutiny.

guided_questions.question: SUBSTITUTE: Which meaning of 'solid' fits best?
guided_questions.hint: Consider: reliable/strong vs. not liquid vs. three-dimensional
guided_questions.explanation: In this context, 'solid' means the alibi was reliable and couldn't be broken down, not that it was a physical object.

trap_examples.description: Choosing the most common meaning without considering context
trap_examples.example: Seeing 'bark' and automatically thinking 'dog sound' when the passage is about trees

trap_examples.description: Picking a word that's close in meaning but wrong in tone
trap_examples.example: Choosing 'stubborn' instead of 'determined' in a positive context

trap_examples.description: Selecting sophisticated words that don't actually fit
trap_examples.example: Using 'erudite' when the context calls for 'simple'

elements.reveal: Always ask: Does this choice maintain the author's intended tone and meaning? If not, it's probably a trap!

content.heading: Key Takeaways
summary_points: üé® Tone and connotation are crucial clues
üîç Use the R.C.S. strategy: Read, Check tone, Substitute & test
üö´ Avoid traps: dictionary defaults, tone mismatches, 'smart' words
